chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Before that, let's talk about the structure of a database

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, you can see that SQL has a database

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: and tables are stored in that database

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: It can be one table or multiple tables

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: It depends on your requirement

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And we store data in those tables which are in the form of rows and columns

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, you can see rows and columns here

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And if I explain it through an example

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, on the right side, you can see an employee table

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And in this employee table, all the values that you can see vertically

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: are called columns

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And all the horizontal values

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: are called rows

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, just like in Excel, it is the same

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: It also has rows and columns

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, it has a total of 5 columns

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Like employee ID, its name, department, age and gender

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And below that, there are values in rows

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And the whole database structure is called RDBMS

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Relational Database Management

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, in the relational database management system

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: there are many tools that you can use

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: to create a database or run SQL queries

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, as I told you, there can be many tables in a database

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And those tables are connected to each other

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Whether it is through the primary key or the foreign key

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, we will understand what is the primary and foreign key in a while

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: But before that, let me show you an example of a typical database

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, you can see this, we call it a database diagram

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, a database diagram is made before you create a database

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: When you have a requirement that you have to store which type of data in the database

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: How many columns will be made or what type of data will be there

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: According to that, you design this table

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And you connect those tables to each other

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So that in the future, if you have to do any analysis

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Or if you have to do any operation, then you can pull data from each other

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And finally, you can get the outcome you want

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, you can see in this, you can call it an e-commerce database

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Or you can call it the data of an online retail website

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, this is just for the purpose of example

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: The actual database has many more tables

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: For example, you can see only 6 tables in this

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, you can see that the first table is of order items

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And there are 3 columns in this

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Order id, product id and quantity

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Now, suppose I want to know who has ordered this

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, what I will do for that

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: First of all, I have an order id

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: I will see that there is another table which has orders

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: In that also, id is used

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: If you see here, there is a line which shows that both the tables are connected

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, what I will do is, I will take the user id from the order table

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And with the help of this user id, I will take the user table

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: If you see here, this user id is matched with the user table id

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Means, it is linked

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, it means that this table is also connected

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, if I go here, I will get the complete user's family

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Like, what is the name of the user, what is his email, what is his gender

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And all the other information is in the tables

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, let's see what are data types

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, whenever you define a column in a table

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, before that, you have to tell what values will come in this column

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And what values you are going to fill in it

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, according to that, you define the data type

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, whatever data type is there, you define it

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: For example, suppose you are making a customer database

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, first of all, you will put the customer id in that

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, the id will be, if you are keeping it in 1, 2, 3, 4 numeric

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, you can tell the data type, which is integer

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Means, numbers will come in it

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, let's see what is the theoretical definition of data type

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, data type of a column defines what value the column can store in a table

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, this is your data type

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And generally, when we make a table

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Then only, we declare the data type of all the columns

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: After that, we classify the data types in 3 categories

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And there are many data types in it

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, first of all, comes your string data type

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, what are the most used data types in it?

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: That is character, char

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And where char means varying character

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, we will see the definition of this in the next slide

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Second comes your data type, numeric

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: In which you use integer, float, and bool

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, in data on time, you will understand that there are data types related to date and time

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, now let's see them in detail

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: The most commonly used data types, which we saw earlier

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: In that, int comes

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Int has full form for integer values

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, if you are keeping 1, 2, 3, 4, etc.

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, we use int for that

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And float is used for decimal numbers

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, if it has decimal numbers, then we use float for that

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And bool is used for boolean values

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: If you want to put true or false values

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, we use bool for that

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Next comes char, which is a fixed length

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, we use char for that

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And then, we have char for the bool

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Next comes char, which is a fixed length string

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And you can put numbers in it

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: You can put letters in it

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And you can put special characters in it

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, char is used a lot

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: For example, if you want to write someone's mail id

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, it will have an at the rate symbol

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Or someone has written 100 score

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Someone has put a dot

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, you can easily store all those things in char

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And where char is the same as char

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: But it has a varying character length

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Next comes your date

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, you can obviously store dates in this

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, the format of date is

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: First comes year, full year, which is 2022

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Then comes month and then date

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And the date time is

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Obviously, it is like date but it has time

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Your time will be in the format of

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Hours, minutes and seconds

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Now, let's talk about

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Primary keys and foreign keys

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Primary key is a unique column

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, it helps you

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: To fetch data from your table

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So,

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: For example, I gave you a customer

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, we will keep the customer id unique

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Means, the id I gave you

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Can't be repeated with anyone else

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, it becomes a unique id

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, we can call it primary key

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Or if I give you an example of a school

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, in a school, there is a class

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: There can be two people with the same name

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: But their roll number won't be the same

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, the roll number can be called primary key

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And in this,

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: You can see the second point

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: That the table has only one primary key

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Generally, it is considered as best practice

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: But it is unique and not null

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Not null means, it has some values

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: It won't be empty

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Because any child in a school

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Can't be without a roll number

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, it will have a roll number

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, it is not null and unique

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Then comes the foreign key

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Foreign key is actually those columns in the table

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Which help you to connect

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: With other tables

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, we saw an example in the starting

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: That the table of order

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Is connecting with the user

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, the one which was connecting

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: On the basis of id, you can call it foreign key

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: You can see that

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Foreign keys can have duplicate values

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And can also have null values

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Next comes the constraints

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, when you fill the data in the table

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: You refine some rules on it

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And we call those rules as constraints

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, these rules help you

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: For data accuracy and reliability

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, for example, I will tell you

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: As I told you, the primary key

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Column is the customer id

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Or the roll number of the child

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, the roll number should never be blank

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, suppose someone is feeding data

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: In the database

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: If he leaves blank, by mistake

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: He will not take the data, he will throw the error

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And will not feed the data in the system

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, to save this type of error

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: We use constraints

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: There are many other uses

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: We will see that in the example

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: We generally declare the constraints

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: With the create table statement

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: You can see the syntax

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, the table has a name

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Then column, then data type

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And finally, the constraint

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, if you want

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: You can put constraints in all columns

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Or if you don't want to put, you can put null values

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: You can leave it blank

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, now we will see

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Some commonly used constraints

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, first is not null

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: We have seen that you can't leave blank values

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Or null values

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Second is unique

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, unique means that

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: No repeated values can come in it

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: No duplicate values can come

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Then comes the primary

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: We have seen that it is a unique column

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, in this, you have a combination of unique and not null

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Then comes foreign

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Foreign is also very important for you

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Because this column will help you

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: To link from other tables

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: That's why it is written here

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Prevent actions that would destroy links between the tables

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, this is very important

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Then comes constraint check

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: You can put a condition in it

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: That values should be positive

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Or values should be greater than this

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, you can do all this with the help of check constraint

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Then comes default constraint

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: You can use this a lot

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Default means that if someone is leaving blank

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: You can put default name in it

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: Then comes create index

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: This index is 0, 1, 2, 3 on the left side

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So, this create index creates numbers

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: So that you can easily identify rows

chunks.title: Data Types, Primary-Foreign Keys & Constraints in
chunks.text: And later you can retrieve data from database

text: Before that, let's talk about the structure of a database So, you can see that SQL has a database and tables are stored in that database It can be one table or multiple tables It depends on your requirement And we store data in those tables which are in the form of rows and columns So, you can see rows and columns here And if I explain it through an example So, on the right side, you can see an employee table And in this employee table, all the values that you can see vertically are called columns And all the horizontal values are called rows So, just like in Excel, it is the same It also has rows and columns So, it has a total of 5 columns Like employee ID, its name, department, age and gender And below that, there are values in rows And the whole database structure is called RDBMS Relational Database Management So, in the relational database management system there are many tools that you can use to create a database or run SQL queries So, as I told you, there can be many tables in a database And those tables are connected to each other Whether it is through the primary key or the foreign key So, we will understand what is the primary and foreign key in a while But before that, let me show you an example of a typical database So, you can see this, we call it a database diagram So, a database diagram is made before you create a database When you have a requirement that you have to store which type of data in the database How many columns will be made or what type of data will be there According to that, you design this table And you connect those tables to each other So that in the future, if you have to do any analysis Or if you have to do any operation, then you can pull data from each other And finally, you can get the outcome you want So, you can see in this, you can call it an e-commerce database Or you can call it the data of an online retail website So, this is just for the purpose of example The actual database has many more tables For example, you can see only 6 tables in this So, you can see that the first table is of order items And there are 3 columns in this Order id, product id and quantity Now, suppose I want to know who has ordered this So, what I will do for that First of all, I have an order id I will see that there is another table which has orders In that also, id is used If you see here, there is a line which shows that both the tables are connected So, what I will do is, I will take the user id from the order table And with the help of this user id, I will take the user table If you see here, this user id is matched with the user table id Means, it is linked So, it means that this table is also connected So, if I go here, I will get the complete user's family Like, what is the name of the user, what is his email, what is his gender And all the other information is in the tables So, let's see what are data types So, whenever you define a column in a table So, before that, you have to tell what values will come in this column And what values you are going to fill in it So, according to that, you define the data type So, whatever data type is there, you define it For example, suppose you are making a customer database So, first of all, you will put the customer id in that So, the id will be, if you are keeping it in 1, 2, 3, 4 numeric So, you can tell the data type, which is integer Means, numbers will come in it So, let's see what is the theoretical definition of data type So, data type of a column defines what value the column can store in a table So, this is your data type And generally, when we make a table Then only, we declare the data type of all the columns After that, we classify the data types in 3 categories And there are many data types in it So, first of all, comes your string data type So, what are the most used data types in it? That is character, char And where char means varying character So, we will see the definition of this in the next slide Second comes your data type, numeric In which you use integer, float, and bool So, in data on time, you will understand that there are data types related to date and time So, now let's see them in detail The most commonly used data types, which we saw earlier In that, int comes Int has full form for integer values So, if you are keeping 1, 2, 3, 4, etc. So, we use int for that And float is used for decimal numbers Like 1.02, 1.5 So, if it has decimal numbers, then we use float for that And bool is used for boolean values If you want to put true or false values So, we use bool for that Next comes char, which is a fixed length So, we use char for that And then, we have char for the bool Next comes char, which is a fixed length string And you can put numbers in it You can put letters in it And you can put special characters in it So, char is used a lot For example, if you want to write someone's mail id So, it will have an at the rate symbol Or someone has written 100 score Someone has put a dot So, you can easily store all those things in char And where char is the same as char But it has a varying character length Next comes your date So, you can obviously store dates in this So, the format of date is First comes year, full year, which is 2022 Then comes month and then date And the date time is Obviously, it is like date but it has time Your time will be in the format of Hours, minutes and seconds Now, let's talk about Primary keys and foreign keys Primary key is a unique column So, it helps you To fetch data from your table So, For example, I gave you a customer So, we will keep the customer id unique Means, the id I gave you Can't be repeated with anyone else So, it becomes a unique id So, we can call it primary key Or if I give you an example of a school So, in a school, there is a class There can be two people with the same name But their roll number won't be the same So, the roll number can be called primary key And in this, You can see the second point That the table has only one primary key Generally, it is considered as best practice But it is unique and not null Not null means, it has some values It won't be empty Because any child in a school Can't be without a roll number So, it will have a roll number So, it is not null and unique Then comes the foreign key Foreign key is actually those columns in the table Which help you to connect With other tables So, we saw an example in the starting That the table of order Is connecting with the user So, the one which was connecting On the basis of id, you can call it foreign key You can see that Foreign keys can have duplicate values And can also have null values Next comes the constraints So, when you fill the data in the table You refine some rules on it And we call those rules as constraints So, these rules help you For data accuracy and reliability So, for example, I will tell you As I told you, the primary key Column is the customer id Or the roll number of the child So, the roll number should never be blank So, suppose someone is feeding data In the database If he leaves blank, by mistake He will not take the data, he will throw the error And will not feed the data in the system So, to save this type of error We use constraints There are many other uses We will see that in the example We generally declare the constraints With the create table statement You can see the syntax So, the table has a name Then column, then data type And finally, the constraint So, if you want You can put constraints in all columns Or if you don't want to put, you can put null values You can leave it blank So, now we will see Some commonly used constraints So, first is not null We have seen that you can't leave blank values Or null values Second is unique So, unique means that No repeated values can come in it No duplicate values can come Then comes the primary We have seen that it is a unique column So, in this, you have a combination of unique and not null Then comes foreign Foreign is also very important for you Because this column will help you To link from other tables That's why it is written here Prevent actions that would destroy links between the tables So, this is very important Then comes constraint check You can put a condition in it That values should be positive Or values should be greater than this So, you can do all this with the help of check constraint Then comes default constraint You can use this a lot Default means that if someone is leaving blank You can put default name in it Then comes create index This index is 0, 1, 2, 3 on the left side So, this create index creates numbers So that you can easily identify rows And later you can retrieve data from database
